I'm surprised to see all the rotational mechanics described without using vectors! I knew you could do it, but I always found that it starts to get messier to not use them when you start to tackle harder problems. But vectors are also a bit more unintuitive at first, especially when trying to describe rotation in a way that's similar to how people are taught linear motion, and I think you've done a really great job at bridging the two in a way that's fun, easy to digest and clear!

The key to misleading students into believing conservation of angular momentum is to link it to linear concepts through fake analogy.
It is illogical to imagine that angular momentum can be an analogy for momentum because angular momentum is defined as L = r x p. It cannot be an analogy of it because it is defined by it.
"It spins faster" is not science. It is wishful thinking. Conservation of angular energy also predicts that she "spins faster". You are presenting an affirming the consequent logical fallacy.

I'm sorry but you are contradicting yourself when your speaking about the record, as you clearly state that Angular Velocity is measured in Radians, so the whole record spins at the exact same Angular Rate throughout, as it's one solid rotating body.
But after this you start speaking about different parts of the record spinning at different linear velocities which contradicts the reality you detailed just previous, as something moving at an angular rate, cannot be moving at a linear rate, as linear implies that something is moving in a straight trajectory, where as Angular speaks of something moving at an angled trajectory around 360 degrees.
So not only is there no linear on a solid rotating body, but there is also no two or more different moving parts, the whole record spins at the same exact Angular rate, so every part of it is moving around 360 degrees together, and not at different distance measurements around, this is not correct.... I personnally don't think about this with the conservation of angular momentum (althought it is conserved). I think it's just a kinematic consequence. Knowing the movmements of the pipe and the water particle for all time, all we have to do is write them in polar coordinates and compare their angles. I got something like this https://www.desmos.com/calculator/hfzl9kqb4e?lang=es (the x variable is the time). When the radial velocity is positive (outwards), the difference is negative (pipe is forward). When the radial velocity is negative (inwards), the difference is positive (the water is forward), but then after a period of time, for some values at least, it gets negative (pipe foward). Note that the disconinuity is caused because that expresion is only valid for x,y>0, but using the corresponding expresions for phi, you should get a continous function.

Dianna, I'm confused why you would claim that "planets are spherical BECAUSE nature is minimizing the energy to spin". I don't think that applies. Planets are almost spherical because of gravity (minimal potential energy), no? Also at 8:05 you ask "what's the smallest moment of inertia you can get" and you say a sphere. If the boundary condition is a given mass/volume, wouldn't a cylinder with minimized diameter or r but large height give the smallest angular momentum. Some boundary condition for r must be given. Otherwise, by just looking at the formula, a cone would have less than a sphere (cone: I = 3/10mr², independent of its height).

You get dizzy when you stop spinning, it's because the fluid in the semicircular canals was pulled toward the sides of your head. When you stop spinning, the fluid flows back to level, from opposite directions. The reason you feel disoriented (dizzy), is because this motion makes no sense to the brain's sense of level. The fluid isn't really spinning. It's just flowing in unexpected directions.

So; if you let the waterpipes point straight up, then the water jets will keep their angular momentum (i.e. keep the same endpart velocity as at the pipes exit holes)?🤔

Just a little correction:
When water goes outside from the pipes and at the same time they are turning around, water will have a tangential speed to front and radial speed to the outward. Because of this reason, they will have a direction near to the front. However as it is seen in the video, they curl back. BUT! this is an illusion. Actually, they are not curled back. Just as an example let's think about not radial but the tangential speed. For a simplification we have two water particles. The first water particle will have a tangential speed when it leaves the pipe and goes forward. Then, the second water particle also goes forward but it will leave the pipe after the first one. Because pipes are turning, the second particle will leave the pipe from a further position. As the two particles just goes on a straight path, the second particle will have a path near to the front compared to first particle. As we think about all particles this way, first left particles looks behind and it seems like while the pipes are turning, water curls back.

As a result, this is the reason of illusion why water just goes on a straight path but not curls back actually.


And also in order to avoid from some misunderstood:
The pipes that has water output to the middle works in the same way. Water particles follows straight lines and as the pipes are turning, they are seems to behave like they are approaching to front and turning outside. There is no words to explaining them with using angular momentum. It is already correct. As it is mentioned in the video, angular momentum is conserved. Also, as I mentioned here, water particles will follow the straight path and they will not curl anywhere, so it is normal that there is no reason to have change in angular momentum.

So also just think about this way.

Have a nice day :)

Here's a thought experiment. Say you're floating down a river on a platform. The river bank is perfectly uniform and causes the water closer to the bank to flow slower than in the center. Therefore your raft is rotating. If you want to move closer to shore, all you've got to do is run to the other side of the raft, every time you're closest to shore. By running away from shore, you push the raft towards it. Right? So, if we scale this up, would this apply to a planet? Like, say we wanted to move the planet further from the sun, could we have everyone drive to work, towards the sun every morning? And then have them drive towards the sun again, in the evening, to go home?

I don't think the curve of the water stream has anything to do with angular momentum. The stream of water isn't a solid object that can have a moment of inertia. It's just a bunch of individual particles coming out one behind another.

The curvature is caused by the increased tangential speed an individual drop has when it leaves the pipe. The faster the angular speed of the sprinkler, the more tangential speed each drop has. Every individual drop travels in a straight line after leaving the tubing. The direction of travel is determined by combining the vectors of the water drop's axial and tangential components.
Watch the Smarter Every Day / Steve Mould video on this subject.

I remember many years ago when a satellite did a Mars fly-by for a gravity-assist.  Because of conservation of (something), energy had to be transmitted from the planet to the tiny satellite.  Considering the mass of the planet vs. the mass of the satellite with their respective motion through the solar system, somebody actually calculated how much the day and the year of Mars was lengthened by transferring that energy to the satellite.  Of course, it was a tiny, tiny fraction of a millisecond.  But I remember being struck by the fact that such a calculation was even possible.

Hi Diana,
Doesn't your sprinkler question (will it lead, go straight or trail) depend on your point of view. The pathway looks curved, but that's an optical illusion. From the point of view of the droplet, each droplet is moving in a straight line. There is a component straight out from the nozzle from the initial velocity, and a component in the direction of rotation. Add those two vectors, and you have a straight line out from the nozzle for any single droplet. It only appears curved because you are following multiple droplets, where the path looks curved. See Smarter Every Day ft Steve Mould https://youtu.be/M4-L8UgPkOk

I think, perhaps, a way to understand the extra energy in the sphere rolling (versus sliding) down the slope would be to tell someone that they need to bring the sphere and the cube to the top of a cliff and then drop them off the edge, straight down.
But, the catch is that the sphere must be spinning when it hits the ground.
This might not seem like a big deal for the little cow sphere, but if it was a 1 ton sphere then you can bet that the person would remember having to put the extra effort into getting it spun up before dropping it.

Hi Guys 😍💋 💝💖

Dear Diana:

Did you know that the word Torque actually comes from the Inquisitor (yes, from the Spanish Inquisition) named Tomas de Torquemada. He was actually the Grand Inquisitor. Anyway, the thing that he did was, he would literally twist the heads off of the Jewish and other Non-Christian "guests" of the Inquisition, imploring them to accept Jesus as their saviour, believing that 'Saving' their imaginary 'Immortal Soul' was more important than any physical discomfort that being tortured to death might have caused them. And so, because he'd twist the heads off the "guests" of the Inquisition, and because his surname was Torquemada, then the word Torque came to mean the rotational equivalent of linear force.


DISCLAIMER
The above information is completely and utterly 100% 'True,' but only so long as we're using apocryphal (or indeed, 'Biblical') definitions of the word 'True!'

Yeah, well... Actually... If the earth stopped spinning, that would NOT be the end of our days... Our days would suddenly take 365 times as long, though, as the earth's orbit around the sun would make the sun shine on every part of the earth exactly once per year... Kind of like how it is at the poles right now.

Other than that... Splendid lesson again (although you could've mentioned that the droplets of water moving inward are experiencing the fictitious coriolis force in the spinning reference frame).
